intro: Trigonella fischeriana var. subracemosa, commonly known as the Indian clover, is a flowering plant native to parts of Asia and Africa. It belongs to the Fabaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and pod-bearing fruits. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring trifoliate leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers arranged in racemose inflorescences. Its seeds are enclosed in slender, cylindrical pods and are often used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. The species is valued for its adaptability to various soil types and its role in ecological and agricultural systems.
